oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Ralph Emery Interviews Ricky Skaggs Parts 1, 2 and 3
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording is from Ralph Emery's (entertainer) interview of Ricky Skaggs (performer) for Nashville's WSM. Tape labeled parts 1, 2 and 3. Recording is from September 05, 1984.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Ralph Emery; Ricky Skaggs
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:02) Ricky Skaggs radio spot for the Ralph Emery Show -- (00:15) Emery introduces Skaggs, and both discuss Skaggs' new album and "Heartbroke" -- (01:57) Emery invites Skaggs to guess what track will follow the success of "Uncle Pen" -- (04:12) Emery and Skaggs discuss the Everly Brothers and Skaggs reveals Paul McCartney wrote "On the Wings of a Nightingale" -- (07:28) Emery jokingly inquires why Skaggs had yet to produce an album with Janie Fricke -- (08:33) Emery invites Skaggs to discuss his comedic flare in the music video for "Honey (Open That Door)" -- (11:38) Emery introduces "Honey (Open That Door)" by Webb Pierce and Skaggs reveals it was an answer to "She's in a Jailhouse Now" -- (13:28) Emery and Skaggs discuss how Skaggs produced the Whites "Pins and Needles," and Skaggs reflects on the experience gained from producing his wife -- (15:38) Emery invites Skaggs to discuss Webb Pierce's "I Don't Care" and both discuss Skaggs' last name -- (16:57) Emery performs his commercial outros and both he and Skaggs say their goodbyes -- (17:38) Emery welcomes Skaggs back to the Ralph Emery Show and Skaggs introduces "The Boy's Night Out" -- (18:04) Emery and Skaggs introduce Bill Monroe's "Uncle Pen" -- (19:48) Emery invites Skaggs to reflect on his success in bluegrass music -- (21:00) Emery inquires what awards Skaggs is up for from the Country Music Awards Association -- (25:09) Emery and Skaggs discuss the time Skaggs spent on Louise Mandrell's trivia show -- (26:45) "Don't Cheat in Our Home Town" is described by Skaggs to be an anti-cheating song -- (28:01) Emery praises "Friendship" and Skaggs describes what it was like to record with Ray Charles -- (31:52) Skaggs and Emery discuss Skaggs' honor to perform with Charles and George Jones -- (34:06) Skaggs reveals to Every that "You May See Me Walkin'" was an original tune -- (34:48) Skaggs and Emery say their goodbyes and perform the commercial outros -- (35:24) Emery welcomes Skaggs back to the Ralph Emery Show and Skaggs reflects on the abundance of performances for "Rocky Top" -- (37:06) Emery invites Skaggs to reflect on his family -- (41:30) Skaggs reveals why there is multiple versions of "It's You Alone" with Gail Davies -- (42:27) Roy Acuff's rendition of "Low and Lonely" is praised by Skaggs -- (44:37) Emery inquires about Skaggs' father's musical career and Ricky Skaggs Day -- (49:20) Emery introduces David Frizzell and Shelby West's "It's a be Together Night -- (50:01) Skaggs impersonates a disc jockey and introduces "You Could've Heard a Heart Break" -- (50:52) Skaggs and Emery joke about the term heartbreak and introduce "I Wouldn't Change If I Could" -- (51:59) Emery and Skaggs say their goodbyes, and Emery performs his commercial outros
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Emery, Ralph; Skaggs, Ricky;
